Sir, I have the honour to submit for the information of the Government of India some extracts from judgments recorded by the High Court of Bombay in Confirmation Case Ho.13 of 1926 (Imperator vs.Mahamad Baksh Sheikh), relating to a point of procedure in a criminal case tried by H.M’s Consul, Ahwaz, in his capacity of Additional Sessions Judge under the Persian Coast and Islands Order in CounciZ, 1907. 2. The trial was held by Mr. Consul Monypenny under the authority of King’s Regulation No.3 of 1916 (copy enclosed), whereby he was empowered to take cognisance of the case without its being committed to him by a magistrate. The reason for this was that Capt. C.C.L. Ryan, H.M*s Vice-Consul, Ahwaz, the only available magistrate who could conveniently have acted as Committing Magistrate, had taken a prominent part, in cooperation with the Persian Police, in the investigation of the crime and was therefore precluded from acting in a magisterial capacity. 3. The sole object with which the King’s Regulation in question was issued was to obviate the necessity for committal in cases where no committing magistrate was readily available. The Regulation lays down that in cases governed by it the procedure to be followed is that prescribed for the bi/fjal ofof v/arrant cases by magistrates. It would appear that this direction was meant to govern the procedure only for that portion of the tU/r\al leading up to what would be the committal stage/ in cases not governed by the Regulation; and that it was not intended that the accused should be deprived of the benefits of a trial by jury or with the aid of assessors. This, however, does not appear from the wording of the Regulation; hence the recommendation of Their Lordships of the High Court of Bombay that either the Regulation should be strictly followed or that it should be amended so as to allow the procedure prescribed for the tfeftal of sessions cases to be followed. 4. Under the Persia (Inland) order in Council, 1899, all serious cases of crime are tried by Provincial Courts with assessors ( vide Article 24a). I am inclined therefore to recommend that the same procedure be sanctioned for the Persian Coast and Islands by the amendment of King*s Regulation Ho.3 of 1916 to permit of the following of the procedure prescribed in section 268 of the Indian Criminal Procedure Code. Before addressing H.M* s Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, I solicit the views of the Government of India on this point. Per Fawcett Js - The appellant in this case, Sub-Assistant Surgeon Mohamad Baksh Sheikh, appeals from his conviction on a charge of murder of his wife at Ahwaz in the southern Khuzistan Province of Persia on the night of the 3rd or 4th March 1926. He was tried by the Consul of Ahwaz in his capacity of an Additional Sessions Judge under the Persian Coast and Islands Order in Council, 1907, with the aid of assessors, and has been sentenced to death. As pointed out in the judgment, held the trial was^Amder the authority of King* s Regulation Ho. 3 of 1916, whereby the Additional Sessions Judge was empowered to take cognizance of the case without having the case committed to him by a Magistrate. The Regulation says the procedure to be followed is that laid down in warrant casesj but under the direction of the Consul General he held the trial with the Assessors, so that the procedure has to a certain extent conformed to that followed in Sessions cases. XX X X Before leaving the case there are a few points of procedure upon which I wish to make a few remarks. First as regards the trial with the aid of the Assessors. Ho doubt this was done in the interests of the defence, and with a view to conform with the law in India. On the other hand, the fact remains that the particular Regulation Ho.3 of 1916, which allows a Session trial without committal by a Magistrate, distinctly states that the Court shall follow the procedure prescribed for the trial of warrant cases by Magistrates. To mix up this procedure with the procedure for trials by Sessions Court is a course that may lead to difficulties in future cases. It seems to me tnat either the Regulation should be strictly followed or that it shouldt \ should he amended so as to allow the procedure prescribed for Sessions cases to be followed, or to provide for some modification of the procedure prescribed for the trial of Warrant Cases. Certainly in the present case the Assessors* opinions have not been helpful to us. But of course that is not a reason for saying that such trials should never be with Assessors; and if the authorities think that it is better to have the aid of Assessors, then proper provision should be made by altering the Regulation in question. x x xx Per Shah Js % * * As regards the procedure, I desire to refer to the terms of the King* Regulation No.3 of 1916 made under Section 55(c) and 56(4) of the Persian Coast arid Islands Order in Council, 1907. It provides expressly that when His Britannic Majesty*s Consul General, as Sessions Judge, and the Judicial Assistant, as an Additional Sessions Judge, takes cognizance of a case without the accused being committed to him by a Magistrate, the procedure to be followed shall be the procedure for the t(i/iial of warrant cases by Magistrates. That is a definite provision; and the association of Assessors at the trial according to that procedure may leadjto difficulties and may at times prove fatal to the validity of a trial. mods.abstract: Correspondence, minute papers, and notes related to The Persian Coasts and Islands Order in Council, 1907. The papers concern the drafting and passing of amendments to the Order in Council and new regulations under the articles of the Order in Council, including 'Sessions Court Original Jurisdiction', 'Abadan Jurisdiction', and 'The Persian Coast and Islands (Amendment No. 2) Order in Council, 1922'. Questions of extending the jurisdictional limits of the Order in Council are considered, as well as applications for re-trial of some cases previously tried in Duzdap. Discussion of the application of a number or Government of India acts is also covered by the file.The correspondence is mostly interdepartmental in nature, between the Foreign Office, India Office, and the Government of India (Foreign and Political Department). Communications from the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, British Legation in Tehran, and the British Consulate in Sistan and Kain are also included.
